sub_topic: Finding the angle of elevation or depression
message_1: A student is standing 20 meters away from a building. The student looks up at the top of the building and measures the angle of elevation to be 60 degrees. What is the height of the building to the nearest meter?
message_2:
To find the height of the building, we can use the tangent function in trigonometry. The tangent of an angle in a right triangle is the ratio of the length of the side opposite the angle to the length of the side adjacent to the angle. In this case, the angle of elevation is 60 degrees, the side adjacent to the angle is the distance from the student to the building (20 meters), and the side opposite the angle is the height of the building (which we want to find).

We can set up the equation:

tan(60°) = height / 20

The tangent of 60 degrees is equal to the square root of 3, so:

√3 = height / 20

Now, we can solve for the height:

height = 20 * √3 ≈ 20 * 1.732 ≈ 34.64

Rounding to the nearest meter, the height of the building is approximately 35 meters.
